awd_titl_txt: Neighborhood Demand Estimation and Ex-Ante Policy Evaluation
awd_abstract_narration:
Government housing policies, such as the Housing Choice Voucher program or the Empowerment Zone program, can change the relative prices of neighborhoods, thereby altering households' demand for neighborhoods. Despite the importance of understanding these neighborhood demand patterns, the existing literature has not estimated neighborhood demand systems intended to capture realistic substitution patterns and evaluate the housing policies. This project seeks to understand how government housing policies would affect demand for neighborhoods, equilibrium neighborhood demographic compositions and price-levels, and ultimately households' well-being. The investigators will develop empirically tractable models of local demand for neighborhoods which place minimal ex ante restrictions on the substitutability of neighborhoods. Using detailed panel data on location choices and credit information, the investigators will estimate the models and further perform program evaluations of existing and yet-to-be enacted government housing programs. 

This project develops and estimates empirically tractable models of local demand for neighborhoods that allow for unrestricted patterns of substitution across neighborhoods and elasticities of demand for particular neighborhoods. The demand model achieves flexibility by positing a large number of observable types of households, with minimal restrictions on how each type's flow indirect utility differs across neighborhoods. Using panel data on the location choices from 1999 to present for 5% of the U.S. population from the NYFRB/Equifax Consumer Credit Panel, the investigators estimate the model's structural parameters by maximum likelihood, exploiting the conditional-choice-probability inversion techniques of Hotz and Miller (1993) and Arcidiacono and Miller (2011) to construct likelihood functions without having to repeatedly solve the full dynamic model. The estimated model facilitates a variety of policy evaluation methodologies, including regression analyses that treat the estimated neighborhood demand elasticities as explanatory variables; partial equilibrium counterfactual policy experiments that study the impact of various subsidies on households' location choices; and equilibrium counterfactual policy experiments that study the impact of various housing policies on neighborhood rent levels and neighborhood demographic compositions. Specifically, the investigators use the estimated model to study the following policy questions: (1) In which locations is the incidence of place-based subsidies -- Empowerment Zones, Enterprise Zones, etc. -- likely to fall on prior zone residents?; (2) Would a large expansion to Section 8-style housing vouchers lead to more mixed-income neighborhoods in equilibrium?; (3) What targeting rules for housing vouchers are most likely to induce households to choose neighborhoods that contribute positively to their children's academic achievement?
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A growing number of researchers and policy makers have explored the possibility of restricting the use of housing vouchers to neighborhoods that positively affect the outcomes of children in voucher-receiving households. In a first paper from this project, we use a dynamic model of optimal location choice to estimate the preferences over neighborhoods (Census tracts) of likely voucher-recipients in Los Angeles. We combine simulations of the model with estimates of how locations affect adult earnings of children from the Opportunity Atlas of Chetty et al. (2018) to understand how possible restrictions on neighborhood choice of voucher-receiving households with children affect both the location decisions of these households as well as the future adult earnings of the children.

The advantage we bring to this literature, relative to previous studies, is that we estimate relative preferences for living in each neighborhood in Los Angeles of all likely voucher-receiving households. Knowledge of these preferences has the potential to aid policy-makers design voucher programs that restrict households to live in high ``Opportunity Atlas'' neighborhoods, but (from the perspective of the renting households) are also desirable places to live, thus maximizing the take-up rate of the voucher and associated adult earnings of children. Although our analysis is only for renting households residing in Los Angeles, presumably our methods and techniques can be applied to all metro areas across the United States.

Proposals to target low-income housing toward neighborhoods that have positive impacts on children?s long-run outcomes are often met with concerns that such policies may fundamentally change the neighborhoods that receive the new low-income housing, offsetting the intended effects of the policy. A second paper from this project develops and estimates an equilibrium modeling framework to study how various approaches to low-income housing development change the long-run racial and economic composition of neighborhoods. When low-income housing is added to a neighborhood, the desirability of that neighborhood relative to other neighborhoods in the metro area may change due to changes in the demographic characteristics brought on by the new low-income housing units. Some people might move in and others move out due to preference or prejudice for the neighborhood?s new demographic makeup, but migration occurs slowly as it is costly to move. Over time, the racial and socio-economic composition of each neighborhood in the metro area may change as people move. Additionally, rents may also adjust to ensure the demand for space in each neighborhood is equal to the supply.

Simulations of the model allow us to directly predict how households move and how neighborhoods demographics and rents change in response to the addition of new low-income housing units in any given neighborhood or set of neighborhoods in a metro area. We find that a large quantity of low-income housing concentrated in a single neighborhood typically causes substantially greater demographic churn than a similar quantity of housing spread across many neighborhoods. Additionally, we find significant variation among high ?Opportunity Atlas? neighborhoods (Chetty et al. 2018) in the extent of demographic churn that new low income housing would cause, providing a guide to policymakers seeking to steer new development to high opportunity neighborhoods while generating minimal offsetting equilibrium effects.


Last Modified: 11/18/2019
Modified by: Jesse Gregory
